data.name: mini-scrollbar
Vivaldi WebMail - Arc Darker Theme
data.description:
I didn't really like any of the default built-in themes of Vivaldi WebMail so I decided to create a nice easy on the eyes dark theme based on Arc Darker theme, a GTK+ theme for Linux distributions.

It's not 100% complete theme rework, so some things will look a bit off. Most of what's completed is in the main mail inbox section.

data.name: Databricks Minimal Notebook
data.description: I find that the default Databricks notebook style wastes way too much space. That's why I created this minimal theme. It gets rid of useless toolbars, eliminates elements that are not needed in notebook view and merges two toolbars.

data.name: GitHub: better-sized tabs in code
data.description:
Change the width of tab characters in code from the default 8 spaces wide to 4 spaces wide. For Ruby code, tabs are 2 spaces wide. (Number of spaces is customizable using the Customize Settings button.) This style applies to code anywhere on GitHub – in repositories and in Gists. For example, code might go from 
really
        long
                indents
to 
more
    reasonable
        indents
This only affects code indented with tab characters (\t). Code indented with multiple spaces will look the same. Is this style still needed? As of 2020-02-18, yes. Some time after I published this user style, GitHub added a feature that recognizes .editorconfig files in a repo and uses the specified tab size when displaying code from that repo. However, GitHub still uses a tab size of 8 in the large number of repos with no .editorconfig, so this user style is still useful.

data.name: All code has custom tab size
data.description: On all websites, change the width of tab characters in code from the default 8 spaces wide to 4 spaces wide, or whatever other size you choose in the selector below. The setting affects all HTML <code> elements. This is like my other style GitHub: better-sized tabs in code, but it applies to all websites. However, it only works on properly marked-up code. This style may not work on some sites that present their code in an unusual way, such as within pre blocks that are not marked as code. If you want to force pre elements to use this tab size even if they are not code, add “pre,” before “code {” in the CSS.
